title: Cat. 120  Bottle, 3rd/4th century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Bottle  
3rd/4th century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, blown; h. 22 cm (8 5/8 in.); diam. 11.5 cm (4 1/2 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.457

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Transparent light-green glass. Blown, trail decorated, and tooled. The rim, rounded by reheating, flares out from a long, cylindrical neck that spreads out gently into a large, piriform body. The wall bends into a tooled base ring with a flat, slightly kicked base with a pontil mark. A very thin trail highlights the lower part of the neck just before it begins to spread out into the body. For a zoomable image, see fig. 120.1.

The neck is broken and repaired. The interior below the repair still retains a thick, dark weathering product that appears as silvery iridescence when viewed through the vessel wall. The weathering crust on the bottle exterior has been almost completely removed and the resulting surface is slightly iridescent.

This is an elegant, simple form that has many variations. The surface currently reads as if one was looking at a mirror through the vessel wall. Compare the silver iridescence on the interior of this flask to the golden iridescence on the exterior of an earlier bottle in the Art Institute of Chicago (cat. 119).

There are no simple bottles that preserve this particular elegant ovoid form. A bottle in the National Museums Scotland has an equally elegant but slightly different profile. A related bottle with a somewhat more full, swelling body was found in Roman Amphipolis dated to the second half of the second or third century A.D. There are several bottles in the Princeton University Art Museum that have related profiles.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Lightfoot, Ancient Glass in National Museums Scotland, p. 97, no. 226.

Antonaras, Fire and Sand, pp. 146–47, nos. 202 and 204.
